node.title: WA watching Omicron very carefully before declaring reopening date, Premier says
node.alt: A close-up of WA Premier Mark McGowan.
node.description: Mark McGowan says it is still his plan to declare in the first half of December a date for the state to open up, but authorities will watch what happens with the new Omicron variant of COVID-19 carefully over the next week.
node.content:
["WA Premier Mark McGowan says it is still his plan to declare in the first half of December a date for the state to open up, but authorities will watch what happens with the new Omicron variant of COVID-19 carefully over the next week.", "Mr McGowan said WA was on track to reach an 80 per cent double dose vaccination rate before December 10, at which point a date for reopening had been promised.", "\"That's the plan at this point,\" Mr McGowan said.", "\"I don't know what's going to happen with Omicron. Omicron didn't exist until three days ago. So let's just watch and see what the World Health Organization, what our health advisers say nationally.\u00a0", "\"I am having a National Cabinet meeting tomorrow with the Prime Minister and the other premiers, we'll just see what they have to say.\"", "Mr McGowan said he was briefed\u00a0this morning by the state's Chief Health Officer on the new variant, the first cases of which have been found in New South Wales in returning travellers from southern Africa.", "The Northern Territory has also recorded its first case of the Omicron variant, in a man who arrived on a repatriation flight.", "The Premier said it was still too early to say what sort of threat the new variant posed to WA.", "\"They don't know yet, so this is the great unknown,\" he said.", "Mr McGowan said authorities would be watching carefully to see what happened across the world and in the eastern states over the next week.", "\"What you find with COVID is things move rapidly,\" he said.", "\"We'll see what they say tomorrow. It may well be that Omicron spreads more rapidly but is not any more lethal, and therefore we can proceed as planned.\"", "
'Stay as we are' until situation clear: AMA
", "Australian Medical Association\u00a0WA president Mark Duncan-Smith\u00a0told ABC Radio Perth the state was in a good position to wait and see what sort of impact the Omicron variant would have, as its borders remained closed.", "", "
WA\u00a0is about to let COVID back in. How will the state's reopening work?
", "\"There's three factors we've got to take into account \u2014 how transmissible it is, we already know it's more transmissible. How dangerous it is, there's indications it's not as bad,\" he said.", "\"But the biggest question at the moment is how effective are the current vaccines, and we won't know that for a good week or two.", "\"That's a good reason for WA to stay as we are right now.\"", "He said fear over the new strain could also lift WA's lagging vaccination rates.", "\"What we need at the moment in WA is COVID pressure, as in, at least the perception it's going to be here very soon, and when we bring down the borders, it will be here. We're basically inviting this virus that is a killer virus to come and live with us,\" he said.", "\"We've already seen it in the far north-west that vaccination rates have gone up significantly following the Katherine Northern Territory outbreak.", "", "
There are hopes\u00a0fears over the new strain could lift WA's low vaccination rates.(ABC News: Keane Bourke)
", "But Dr Duncan-Smith said he was unsure how the health system would cope with an outbreak, as WA already had\u00a0the lowest number of ventilated intensive care unit (ICU) beds per head of population in the country.", "He said the health system could ramp up from about 150 ventilated ICU beds to 600, but the system still had\u00a0to cope with increasing demand from areas outside of COVID.", "\"Just because there's an outbreak, it doesn't mean brain tumors, heart attacks, pneumonia, sepsis \u2014\u00a0reasons people get put into ICU \u2014\u00a0it doesn't mean these disappear. So if our ICU's are already full, then we're going to need that extra capacity to deal with COVID,\" he said.", "", "
What COVID-19 travel insurance doesn't cover you for(Emilia Terzon)
"]
